content_scrubbed:
I went to Waseda and my friend went to Keio at the same time, so I got a glimpse of what it was like at both places.

As far as housing goes, I got lucky with this one. I lived in the international student dormitory right across from campus, so commuting was a cinch. My friend at Keio (along with other friends at Waseda) had to live in apartments or with host families elsewhere in Tokyo, so commuting to school was a pain.

I was a SILS (School of International Liberal Studies) student at Waseda, so I got to take language classes and liberal_arts classes. Just avoid the liberal_arts classes taught by Japanese professors--I took mine from mostly visiting professors and they were awesome. My required language classes were... Well, let me preface this by saying that I couldn't get into the level I actually was because of my kanji level at the time of the placement test. So I was stuck learning old grammar points for most of the year. So I was bored a lot in my Japanese classes (1 hour, four days a week). The teachers were alright, I guess. Plus we had Japanese Language Education majors come in to the class about once a week for conversation. Oh, and all of my classes transferred back to count towards either my major or graduation.

My friend at Keio was a "Bekka Program" student because she was a language major. She took mostly language courses, plus a couple liberal_arts classes. If I remember correctly, she got a lot out of her language classes.

As far as social aspects go... I am biased towards Waseda. The campus and surrounding area (Takadanobaba station) have a "college student" feel where there are lots of places to get cheap eats and hang out. Plus, it[.] on the west side of the Yamanote, closer to Shin-okubo, Shinjuku, Harajuku, Shibuya and Ikebukuro.
